text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- A Bulgarian court ruling is expected against a local illegal producer of audio CD's -- the first case in the country when an illegal maker of CD's has been brought to justice.

-- Bulgaria's Agriculture ministry should immediately estimate the country's stockpiles of cooking oil to prevent a shortage similar to current grain crisis caused by excessive exports, an Oil Producers Union senior official said. @
-- Bulgaria's state insurance company Bulstrad shareholders decided to raise its capital to 600.6 million levs from 400.4 million levs. Bulstrad posted 151.3 million levs pretax profit for 1996.

-- Bulgaria's Chief Prosecutor's Ofiice said it had charged former agriculture minister Vassil Chichibaba and three of his deputies with complicity in excessive wheat exports in 1995 and 1996 which had led to a severe grain shortage. @

-- Bulgaria's interim cabinet should allow the State Savings Bank (SSB) to attract deposits in foreign currency from the population because the local currency, the lev, would be freely convertible in hard currency in the country after the planned introduction of a tough fixed exchange rate mechanism, the currency board system, Steve Hanke from the John Hopkins University in Baltimore said.
-- Bulgaria's private Capitalbank shareholders decided to raise the bank's capital to 12 billion levs from 500 million levs, Capitalbank's board chairman Angel Parvanov said.
-- Bulgaria's caretaker cabinet is expected to raise central heating charges by 70 percent from April 1, Energy ministry officials said.
-- Bulgaria's interim government is expected to raise the basic minimum income, to which pensions and social benefits are pegged, to 17,000 levs from 10,000 levs, Social care ministry officials said.

-- Bulgaria is expected to seek assistance from the Russian special services in the investigatioon of the murder of Bulgaria's former prime minister Andrei Loukanov, Sofia City prosecutor Nestor Nestorov said. @
Loukanov was gunned down in broad daylight in front of his home in Sofia in October last year.
-- Bulgaria's National Social Insurance Institute is expected to propose to the cabinet to raise pensions five-fold from May 1. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 8569
